0.57.text:
Do the chemicals in a thanksgiving tofurkey 
send you to sleep?

5.50.text:
Every year around the end of November, 
you hear stories about something in

9.62.text:
turkey meat that makes you want to to curl up 
and sleep after Thanksgiving dinner.

14.57.text:
But is this phenomenon limited to 
meat-eaters alone,

19.72.text:
or does the soy-based tofurkey come 
with the same soporific side effects?

25.24.text:
That "something" is triptophan -- one of the 
essential amino acids we all

31.98.text:
Tryptophan is an essential building block 
of proteins in our bodies.

35.92.text:
But it's also used in the production of seratonin 
-- a neurotransmitter that helps

40.01.text:
regulate sleep patterns amongst 
other things.

44.75.text:
o doze off after thanksgiving 
dinner -- the argument goes --

49.17.text:
is because turkey meat is stuffed 
full of tryptophan.

53.02.text:
But what happens if you eat 
tofurkey instead?

56.26.text:
According to the United States 
Department of Agriculture,

60.08.text:
tofu -- which as you might have guessed 
is what most tofurkeys are made of --

64.07.text: contains less than half the tryptophan

68.01.text:
On the other hand, the Ministry of Education, Culture, 
Sports, Science and Technology

74.88.text:
claims tofu has over twice the tryptophan 
content as turkey.

79.35.text:
The bottom line though is tofurkey 
contains tryptophan.

84.15.text: And depending on whether you have a US

86.76.text:
or Japanese tofu-based tofurkey, it could 
have an even greater knock-out effect

96.96.text: Thanksgiving tryptophan-induced torpor is a myth.

101.86.text: As Matt Shipman explains in the article linked below,

105.27.text:
you can't get enough of the chemical into 
the brain simply by eating turkey -- or tofurkey --

113.39.text: Instead, that post thanksgiving need to nap

117.14.text:
is probably due to your body doing its best 
to digest the results of your overindulgence

122.96.text:
Either that, or a subconscious desire to 
avoid cleaning up after the meal's finished.

128.62.text: And as a final piece of trivia,

130.66.text:
if you want to know what food has the 
highest levels of tryptophan,

136.51.text:
which comes in at over five times the amount 
of tryptophan as roast turkey,

141.84.text:
So if you really want to experiment with 
Thanksgiving-induced lethargy,

146.72.text: you know what to cook next year.

149.05.text:

risk don't forget to subscribe to Risk Science
